summary: The case of Boner v. the United Kingdom (Application no. 18711/91) concerns a breach of Article 6 para. 3 (c) of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) by the United Kingdom. The applicant, Mr. Anthony Boner, was arrested and charged with murder in 1989 and was denied access to a lawyer during the initial 24-hour period following his arrest, contrary to the United Kingdom's domestic law and the ECHR. The applicant claimed that this denial of access to a lawyer breached his right to a fair trial under Article 6 para. 3 (c) of the ECHR. The European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) held that there was a violation of Article 6, paragraph 3(c) of the Convention, which guarantees the right to a fair trial, including the right to legal assistance. The Court found that the possibility of Mr. Boner suffering substantive injustice due to his lack of legal representation was remote, but the "interests of justice" required that Mr. Boner be given free legal assistance for the hearing of his appeal. The Court awarded Mr. Boner 7,500.28 pounds sterling and 16,275.79 French francs, less the amount already paid, in respect of legal costs and expenses.
